urls.title: Home | Sony Future Filmmaker Awards
urls.description: Win a visit to Sony Pictures studio and gain exclusive insight into the industry. Submit your best short films for free by December 13, 2022 Free to enter, the Sony Future Filmmaker Awards is a major new program for short films providing an exceptional opportunity for creators and filmmakers from around the world. The 30 successful filmmakers will be flown to Los Angeles to visit Sony Pictures studio in Culver City, California, where they’ll gain unparalleled insight into the world of cinema and exclusive

data.text:
The Sony Future Filmmaker Awards closes on 13 December 2022 and is open to all filmmakers. 

There are three competitions to choose from and the jury panel for this year includes Academy Award-winning cinematographer Sir Roger Deakins

Enter for free at https://t.co/ZFBTAL8Ovo. https://t.co/LsPrlHOqUR

urls.title: Welcome! You are invited to join a webinar: CREATIVE DOCUMENTARY MASTERCLASS SERIES #1 . After registering, you will receive a confirmation email about joining the webinar.
urls.description: KANAVAL: A PEOPLE'S HISTORY OF HAITI IN SIX CHAPTERS With filmmakers: Eddie Hutton-Mills and Leah Gordon (Co-directors), Natasha Dack Ojumu (Producer) and Xanna Ward Dixon (Editor). Hosted by: Lynn Nwokorie (Editorial Consultant and Executive Producer for documentary) The first in a special online series of creative documentary masterclasses aimed at inspiring the next generation of filmmakers and creatives working in the documentary field, join session guide Lynn Nwokorie and the filmmakers of Kanaval: A People’s History of Haiti in Six Chapters. This session will explore the creative journey of the project from how the team initially formed their collaboration to developing their visual language with a wealth of archive, observational footage and rich character testimonies. Delving into the editing process and building narrative to create a powerful and deeply cinematic re-framing of Haiti’s history. About the film: KANAVAL is a visually arresting feature documentary that is set in t

“I genuinely have not found any distributors or programmers like Other Cinemas in London and would love for them to get the support to grow what they do so more people can enjoy their work." @RoxyRezvany  (Little Pyongyang)
Their various screenings include three weekend festivals, the most recent of which was Radical Films, Radical Forms (25-27 March) exploring revolutionary Arab documentary cinema.

Other Cinemas deliver film festival quality programming, with accessibility at its heart, and all screenings are free. They only screen the works of Black and POC filmmakers and have majority (75%) Black and POC audiences, reflecting the diversity of Brent. https://t.co/o6muaugpyL

Arising from Brent’s Borough of Culture 2020, they take independent cinema out of typical institutions & into community spaces where attendees are welcomed. Many of these institutions have failed racialised communities & Other Cinemas aims to rectify without compromising quality https://t.co/9bGYThYALq

urls.description: Supporting UK films to reach international audiences.

data.text:

https://t.co/cgpldgksfc https://t.co/OM3kfbyJ9X
“If you spend any time with a camera team, you can see how they love new technology. I want to see that mentality come to the new energy space.” - Laurence Johnson
“We don’t all have to be experts here. We have to listen to experts, give them time, give them space and give them the power to try new technology.” - Roxy Erickson

“The generator project brings the industry and local councils together to answer energy needs. The next question is how do we support our suppliers to access new technology and to come together?” - Amelia Price

“The film industry is a culture maker with a big voice and big influence. We can change the culture where it comes to sustainable energy.” - Roxy Erickson on what the film industry can do alongside legislative changes

“We have a lot of shoots in Paris with productions wondering how they will power their projects with diesel   being banned. This is where sustainable energy sources need to come in. Once legislation comes in, choices get made.” - Lola Legros on the importance of legislation
“Ego equals emissions. Having power saving conversations early with all different stakeholders involved can save on difficult decisions down the line” - Roxy Erickson
Roxy Erickson on simple steps businesses can take to increase sustainability- “The post office taught all of their drivers to be safer on the road and reduced their emissions by 11%”
Amelia Price - “Learning and research times can be shared across jobs. Every studio is so much more aware of issues with sustainability now and we are being given much longer lead times for work”

Opening remarks on the challengers the industry faces: 

Roxy Erickson - “35% of emissions are from road vehicles & another 15% from generator usage”

Amelia Price - “Timescale is the barrier. We live in a moving industry & there isn’t framework to learn about sustainability” https://t.co/k3G83dVCQ2

Our panel at @tlgfocus today has just begun. Film London’s Sustainability Manager Laurence Johnson moderates Sustainable Film: Reducing our Emissions, exploring the challenges of addressing both air quality and greenhouse gas emissions from the film and TV sector. https://t.co/lG5KNFgfFm

“There’s no point going renewable with your electrical supply if you doesn’t do the same with your energy supply” - Michelle Jenkins on the SSE 100% renewable energy supply of the upcoming Victoria Park Grid Project
“Our aim is to create an universal EU tool for film production” - Zuzana Bieliková
“Six years of partnerships including all reports are available online. We believe we have left a project heritage for the future” - Zuzana Bieliková

“The aim of Green Screen was to Inspire and educate the nomadic world or filmmaking.For us it was very much about working together and seeing how we can start to make some real changes” - Michelle Jenkins

We are delighted to be celebrating six years of the European Green Screen partnership at @tlgfocus. Zuzana Bieliková, @FilmSlovak_SFC Film Commissioner is joined by Film London’s Head of Production Services, Michelle Jenkins. https://t.co/C91A5Ylha9

urls.description: To mark World AIDS Day, DOKBOX presents Ximei. During a government-sponsored blood campaign, peasants from China’s Henan Province queued in front of vans to sell their blood for approximately 5 dollars, a month’s wages.  300,000 people were infected with HIV from contaminated equipment and transfusions, sparking a full-blown epidemic, followed by…

data.text:

urls.description: If your personal plans for 2023 have anything to do with filmmaking, then you’re in luck, because making films just got easier.

data.text:
. @ShootingPeople are back to in-person events next year🥳 

Join them at @RichMixLondon for a #filmnetworking party. Meet other #independentfilm creatives, watch some great shorts + learn from industry pros.

📆10 JAN | 7PM  🎉 

Tickets: https://t.co/DAABjb442O https://t.co/QmQJHDwOS7

"Jack was an exceptional talent to work with on The Rev, my first written and directed short film. From the very beginning he was a true collaborator... it was just total joy to see him bring the character to life."

@FabiaMartin (writer/director, The Rev)

As an actor, Jack can currently be seen as a series regular in Ten Percent, @PrimeVideo’s English reboot of Call my Agent, and he was on BBC1 Stefan Golaszewski’s forthcoming drama Marriage. Jack has also featured in British independent films The Levelling and Journey’s End.

He produced the film alongside @sarcher88, Emma Wellbelove and Alastair Mavor. It premiered in @BFI London Film Festival’s LFF for Free programme and has screened at Cambridge and Underwire. https://t.co/hGBXeziA8G

In Film London/ @bfinetwork -supported comedy short The Rev (written and directed by @FabiaMartin), Jack brought warmth, humour and surprise to the titular character in a joyous performance. https://t.co/5W0xIk0Y8B

As a writer/performer, Jack’s debut play Cruise premiered at the Duchess Theatre, London in Summer 2021, and was nominated for an @OlivierAwards for Best New Play. Jack is also developing original scripted dramas Generation with @FremantleHQ and Baby Face with @EmanataStudios. https://t.co/SWXJXP68o6

tweets.text: Their various screenings include three weekend festivals, the most recent of which was Radical Films, Radical Forms (25-27 March) exploring revolutionary Arab documentary cinema.

Other Cinemas deliver film festival quality programming, with accessibility at its heart, and all screenings are free. They only screen the works of Black and POC filmmakers and have majority (75%) Black and POC audiences, reflecting the diversity of Brent. https://t.co/o6muaugpyL

Arising from Brent’s Borough of Culture 2020, they take independent cinema out of typical institutions & into community spaces where attendees are welcomed. Many of these institutions have failed racialised communities & Other Cinemas aims to rectify without compromising quality https://t.co/9bGYThYALq

urls.title: Vacancy: Head of Film Hub North
urls.description: Join our team

tweets.text:
#JobVacancy: Want to play an active role in shaping the work we do to support film exhibitors and filmmakers in the North of England?

Apply now to be the next Head of Film Hub North: https://t.co/LyLXidaZxv 

Deadline: Mon 9 Jan 2023 https://t.co/OncgQWP5B8
“We don’t all have to be experts here. We have to listen to experts, give them time, give them space and give them the power to try new technology.” - Roxy Erickson

“The generator project brings the industry and local councils together to answer energy needs. The next question is how do we support our suppliers to access new technology and to come together?” - Amelia Price

“The film industry is a culture maker with a big voice and big influence. We can change the culture where it comes to sustainable energy.” - Roxy Erickson on what the film industry can do alongside legislative changes

“We have a lot of shoots in Paris with productions wondering how they will power their projects with diesel   being banned. This is where sustainable energy sources need to come in. Once legislation comes in, choices get made.” - Lola Legros on the importance of legislation
“Ego equals emissions. Having power saving conversations early with all different stakeholders involved can save on difficult decisions down the line” - Roxy Erickson
Roxy Erickson on simple steps businesses can take to increase sustainability- “The post office taught all of their drivers to be safer on the road and reduced their emissions by 11%”
Amelia Price - “Learning and research times can be shared across jobs. Every studio is so much more aware of issues with sustainability now and we are being given much longer lead times for work”

Opening remarks on the challengers the industry faces: 

Roxy Erickson - “35% of emissions are from road vehicles & another 15% from generator usage”

Amelia Price - “Timescale is the barrier. We live in a moving industry & there isn’t framework to learn about sustainability” https://t.co/k3G83dVCQ2

Our panel at @tlgfocus today has just begun. Film London’s Sustainability Manager Laurence Johnson moderates Sustainable Film: Reducing our Emissions, exploring the challenges of addressing both air quality and greenhouse gas emissions from the film and TV sector. https://t.co/lG5KNFgfFm
“Our aim is to create an universal EU tool for film production” - Zuzana Bieliková
“Six years of partnerships including all reports are available online. We believe we have left a project heritage for the future” - Zuzana Bieliková

“The aim of Green Screen was to Inspire and educate the nomadic world or filmmaking.For us it was very much about working together and seeing how we can start to make some real changes” - Michelle Jenkins

We are delighted to be celebrating six years of the European Green Screen partnership at @tlgfocus. Zuzana Bieliková, @FilmSlovak_SFC Film Commissioner is joined by Film London’s Head of Production Services, Michelle Jenkins. https://t.co/C91A5Ylha9
